* [How to run your own LanguageTool server](https://dev.languagetool.org/http-server)
* [HTTP API documentation](https://languagetool.org/http-api/swagger-ui/#!/default/post_check)

For more information, please see our homepage at https://languagetool.org,
[this README](https://github.com/languagetool-org/languagetool/blob/master/languagetool-standalone/README.md),
and [CHANGES](https://github.com/languagetool-org/languagetool/blob/master/languagetool-standalone/CHANGES.md).

The LanguageTool core (this repo) is freely available under the LGPL 2.1 or later.

## Docker

--
   server                      Runs server version of LanguageTool
```

## Alternate way to build from source

Before start: you will need to clone from GitHub and install Java 17 and Apache Maven.

Warning: a complete clone requires downloading more than 500 MB and needs more than 1500 MB on disk.
This can be reduced if you only need the last few revisions of the master branch
by creating a shallow clone:

ToolUse.content: Now let's look at how we might integrate LanguageTool with your Rust email client:

Json.stdout:
### Example

```bash
> ltrs ping # to check if the server is alive
PONG! Delay: 110 ms
> ltrs languages # to list all languages
[
  {
    "name": "Arabic",
    "code": "ar",
    "longCode": "ar"
  },
  {
    "name": "Asturian",
    "code": "ast",
    "longCode": "ast-ES"
  },
  # ...
]
> ltrs check --text "Some phrase with a smal mistake"  # codespell:ignore smal
{
  "language": {
    "code": "en-US",
    "detectedLanguage": {
      "code": "en-US",
      "confidence": 0.99,
      "name": "English (US)",
      "source": "ngram"
    },
    "name": "English (US)"
  },
--
### Example

```rust
use languagetool_rust::api::{check, server::ServerClient};
use std::borrow::Cow;

#[tokio::main]
async fn main() -> Result<(), Box<dyn std::error::Error>> {
    let client = ServerClient::from_env_or_default();

    let req = check::Request::default()
        .with_text("Some phrase with a smal mistake");  // # codespell:ignore smal

    println!(
        "{}",
        serde_json::to_string_pretty(&client.check(&req).await?)?
    );
    Ok(())
}
```

### Feature Flags

Below are listed the various feature flags you can enable when compiling LTRS.

#### Default Features

- **cli**: Adds command-line related methods for multiple structures.
  This feature is required to install the LTRS CLI,
  and enables the following features: **annotate**, **color**, **html**, **markdown**, **multithreaded**, **typst**.
- **native-tls**: Enables TLS functionality provided by `native-tls`.
--
  in the [Model | Example Value](https://languagetool.org/http-api/swagger-ui/#!/default/)
  but might be present in some cases. All added fields are stored in a hashmap as
  JSON values.

## Related Projects

Here are listed some projects that use LTRS.

- [`null-ls`](https://github.com/jose-elias-alvarez/null-ls.nvim):
  Neovim plugin with LTRS builtin ([see PR](https://github.com/jose-elias-alvarez/null-ls.nvim/pull/997))
- [`languagetool-code-comments`](https://github.com/dustinblackman/languagetool-code-comments):
  uses LTRS to check for grammar errors within code comments

*Do you use LTRS in your project? Contact me so I can add it to the list!*

## Contributing

Contributions are more than welcome!

First, check out the [CHANGELOG](https://github.com/jeertmans/languagetool-rust/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md)
guide for detailed information about how to contribute to this project.

Should you have any question, feel free to reach out via:
[Issues](https://github.com/jeertmans/languagetool-rust/issues) for bugs,
[Pull requests](https://github.com/jeertmans/languagetool-rust/pulls) for code contributions
or [Discussions](https://github.com/jeertmans/languagetool-rust/discussions) for anything else.

Response.content:
Based on my research, here's how LanguageTool works and how you could integrate it with your TUImail project:

## How LanguageTool Works

LanguageTool is an open-source grammar, style, and spell checker that supports over 25 languages. It's primarily written in Java but can be accessed through various methods:

1. **Server Mode**: LanguageTool can run as an HTTP server that accepts text and returns grammar/spelling suggestions via a REST API.

2. **Library Integration**: It can be integrated directly into applications using language-specific bindings.

3. **Command-line Tool**: It can be used as a standalone command-line tool.

## Key Features of LanguageTool

- Grammar checking (not just spelling)
- Style suggestions
- Multi-language support (25+ languages)
- Customizable rules
- Context-aware corrections
- API access for integration

## Integration Options for Your Rust Email Client

There are several Rust crates available for integrating with LanguageTool:

1. **languagetool-rust (v3.0.0-rc.1)**: 
   - More modern and actively maintained
   - Provides comprehensive API bindings
   - Supports multiple formats (HTML, Markdown, etc.)
   - Has CLI capabilities built-in
   - Requires Rust 1.82.0

2. **languagetool (v0.1.2)**:
   - Simpler bindings for the LanguageTool server
   - Less actively maintained

## How Integration Would Work

1. **Server-based approach**:
   - Run LanguageTool as a local server (Java-based)
   - Use the Rust client to send text to the server for checking
   - Process and display the results in your TUI

2. **Example integration code**:
   ```rust
   use languagetool_rust::api::{check, server::ServerClient};
   
   async fn check_text(text: &str) -> Result<check::Response, Box<dyn std::error::Error>> {
       let client = ServerClient::from_env_or_default();
       let req = check::Request::default().with_text(text);
       client.check(&req).await
   }
   ```

3. **Displaying results in TUI**:
   - Parse the response to extract errors and suggestions
   - Highlight errors in the text editor component
   - Show suggestions when the user selects an error

## Comparison with Your Current Spell Checker

Your current spell checker has:
- ~15,000 curated English words
- Visual highlighting of misspelled words
- Suggestions for corrections
- Personal dictionary support

LanguageTool would provide:
- Full grammar checking (not just spelling)
- Style suggestions
- Support for 25+ languages
- More sophisticated context-aware corrections
- Potentially better accuracy for complex grammatical issues

## Implementation Considerations

1. **Performance**: LanguageTool is more resource-intensive than a simple spell checker. You might want to:
   - Check text asynchronously to avoid UI freezes
   - Implement a debounce mechanism to avoid checking on every keystroke

2. **Dependency Management**: You'd need to:
   - Either bundle the LanguageTool server with your application
   - Or provide instructions for users to install it separately

3. **User Experience**:
   - Consider how to display both spelling and grammar errors distinctly
   - Design an interface for showing more complex suggestions

4. **Offline Support**:
   - LanguageTool can run locally, maintaining your app's offline capabilities

Would you like me to provide a more detailed implementation plan or example code for integrating LanguageTool with your TUImail project?

Json.stdout:
## Using n-gram datasets
> LanguageTool can make use of large n-gram data sets to detect errors with words that are often confused, like __their__ and __there__.
*Source: [https://dev.languagetool.org/finding-errors-using-n-gram-data](https://dev.languagetool.org/finding-errors-using-n-gram-data)*
[Download](http://languagetool.org/download/ngram-data/) the n-gram dataset(s) onto your local machine and unzip them into a local ngrams directory:
│  ├─ ngrams/
│  │  │  ├─ 1grams/
│  │  │  ├─ 2grams/
│  │  │  ├─ 3grams/
│  │  │  ├─ 1grams/
│  │  │  ├─ 2grams/
│  │  │  ├─ 3grams/
Mount the local ngrams directory to the `/ngrams` directory in the Docker container [using the `-v` configuration](https://docs.docker.com/engine/reference/commandline/container_run/#read-only) and set the `languageModel` configuration to the `/ngrams` folder.
docker run --rm -it -p 8010:8010 -e langtool_languageModel=/ngrams -v /home/john/ngrams:/ngrams:ro erikvl87/languagetool

Response.content:
Based on my research, here's what I can tell you about LanguageTool's memory and CPU requirements:

## LanguageTool Memory and CPU Requirements

### Memory Requirements

1. **Default Java Heap Settings**:
   - From the Docker configuration, the recommended settings are:
   - Minimum heap size (Xms): 512MB
   - Maximum heap size (Xmx): 1GB

2. **Real-world Usage**:
   - The base LanguageTool server without n-gram data typically requires 500MB-1GB of RAM
   - With n-gram data (for more accurate suggestions), memory usage increases significantly

3. **N-gram Data Impact**:
   - If you use n-gram data for improved error detection, memory requirements increase substantially
   - Full n-gram datasets can require several GB of additional memory

### CPU Requirements

1. **Base Requirements**:
   - LanguageTool is primarily CPU-bound rather than memory-bound for processing
   - Any modern CPU should be able to run it, but performance scales with processing power

2. **Processing Speed**:
   - Text checking speed depends on:
     - CPU performance
     - Text complexity
     - Number of enabled rules
     - Language being checked

3. **Concurrency**:
   - For multiple simultaneous requests, CPU becomes more important than memory
   - Multi-core processors will perform better for server deployments

### Comparison with Your Current Spell Checker

Your current spell checker in TUImail has:
- ~15,000 curated English words
- Lightweight implementation using HashSet-based word lookup
- Minimal memory footprint

LanguageTool will require:
- Significantly more memory (500MB-1GB minimum)
- More CPU resources for grammar checking
- Java runtime environment

### Integration Considerations

1. **Client-Server Architecture**:
   - The most efficient approach would be to run LanguageTool as a separate server process
   - Your Rust application would communicate with it via HTTP API
   - This isolates the memory usage to a separate process

2. **Resource Management**:
   - You could start/stop the LanguageTool server on demand to conserve resources
   - The languagetool-rust crate provides Docker integration for this purpose

3. **Performance Optimization**:
   - Use asynchronous requests to avoid UI freezes
   - Implement request throttling/debouncing
   - Consider checking text in chunks rather than all at once

4. **User Experience**:
   - Provide options to enable/disable grammar checking
   - Allow users to configure memory usage (via Java heap settings)
   - Consider offering a "lightweight mode" that uses your existing spell checker

### Practical Recommendation

For a terminal-based email client where resource efficiency is important, you might want to:

1. Make LanguageTool integration optional and off by default
2. Provide clear documentation about the memory requirements
3. Implement a hybrid approach where:
   - Your lightweight spell checker runs in real-time as users type
   - LanguageTool grammar checking is available on-demand (e.g., via a keyboard shortcut)

This would give users the best of both worlds - fast, efficient spell checking by default with the option for more comprehensive grammar checking when needed.

Would you like more specific information about any aspect of LanguageTool's resource requirements or integration approaches?

A fast, low-resource Natural Language Processing and Error Correction library.
version: 0.6.4
license: MIT OR Apache-2.0
rust-version: unknown
documentation: https://docs.rs/nlprule/0.6.4
repository: https://github.com/bminixhofer/nlprule
crates.io: https://crates.io/crates/nlprule/0.6.4
features:
 +default        = [regex-onig]
  onig           = [dep:onig]
  regex-onig     = [onig]
  bin            = [clap, env_logger]
  clap           = [dep:clap]
  compile        = [regex-syntax, serde-xml-rs, xml-rs, roxmltree, serde_json, srx/from_xml, regex-all-test]
  env_logger     = [dep:env_logger]
  fancy-regex    = [dep:fancy-regex]
  regex-all-test = [regex-onig, regex-fancy]
  regex-fancy    = [fancy-regex]
  regex-syntax   = [dep:regex-syntax]
  roxmltree      = [dep:roxmltree]
  serde-xml-rs   = [dep:serde-xml-rs]
  serde_json     = [dep:serde_json]
  xml-rs         = [dep:xml-rs]

nlprule

A fast, low-resource Natural Language Processing and Error Correction library written in Rust. nlprule implements a rule- and lookup-based approach to NLP using resources from [LanguageTool](https://github.com/languagetool-org/languagetool).
Python Usage Install: `pip install nlprule` Use: ```python from nlprule import Tokenizer, Rules tokenizer = Tokenizer.load("en") rules = Rules.load("en", tokenizer) ``` ```python rules.correct("He wants that you send him an email.") # returns: 'He wants you to send him an email.' rules.correct("I can due his homework.") # returns: 'I can do his homework.' for s in rules.suggest("She was not been here since Monday."): print(s.start, s.end, s.replacements, s.source, s.message) # prints: # 4 16 ['was not', 'has not been'] WAS_BEEN.1 Did you mean was not or has not been? ``` ```python for sentence in tokenizer.pipe("A brief example is shown."):

Json.stdout:
A fast, low-resource Natural Language Processing and Error Correction library written in Rust. nlprule implements a rule- and lookup-based approach to NLP using resources from [LanguageTool](https://github.com/languagetool-org/languagetool).
- Fast, low-resource NLP suited for running:
All credit for the resources used in nlprule goes to [LanguageTool](https://github.com/languagetool-org/languagetool) who have made a Herculean effort to create high-quality resources for Grammatical Error Correction and broader NLP.

| ------- | --------------------------------------------- | ----------------- | ---------- | ------------ | ----------------- |
| English | 843 (100%)                                    | 3725 (~ 85%)      | 5.2        | 1            | 1.7 - 2.0         |
| German  | 486 (100%)                                    | 2970 (~ 90%)      | 5.2        | 1            | 2.4 - 2.8         |
| Spanish | *Experimental support. Not fully tested yet.* |

See the [benchmark issue](https://github.com/bminixhofer/nlprule/issues/6) for details.

## Projects using nlprule

- [prosemd](https://github.com/kitten/prosemd-lsp): a proofreading and linting language server for markdown files with VSCode integration.
- [cargo-spellcheck](https://github.com/drahnr/cargo-spellcheck): a tool to check all your Rust documentation for spelling and grammar mistakes.

Please submit a PR to add your project!

## Acknowledgements

All credit for the resources used in nlprule goes to [LanguageTool](https://github.com/languagetool-org/languagetool) who have made a Herculean effort to create high-quality resources for Grammatical Error Correction and broader NLP.

## License

nlprule is licensed under the MIT license or Apache-2.0 license, at your option.

The nlprule binaries (`*.bin`) are derived from LanguageTool v5.2 and licensed under the LGPLv2.1 license. nlprule statically and dynamically links to these binaries. Under LGPLv2.1 §6(a) this does not have any implications on the license of nlprule itself.

Json.stdout:
nlprule

A fast, low-resource Natural Language Processing and Error Correction library written in Rust. nlprule implements a rule- and lookup-based approach to NLP using resources from [LanguageTool](https://github.com/languagetool-org/languagetool).
Python Usage Install: `pip install nlprule` Use: ```python from nlprule import Tokenizer, Rules tokenizer = Tokenizer.load("en") rules = Rules.load("en", tokenizer) ``` ```python rules.correct("He wants that you send him an email.") # returns: 'He wants you to send him an email.' rules.correct("I can due his homework.") # returns: 'I can do his homework.' for s in rules.suggest("She was not been here since Monday."): print(s.start, s.end, s.replacements, s.source, s.message) # prints: # 4 16 ['was not', 'has not been'] WAS_BEEN.1 Did you mean was not or has not been? ``` ```python for sentence in tokenizer.pipe("A brief example is shown."): for token in sentence: print( repr(token.text).ljust(10), repr(token.span).ljust(10), repr(token.tags).ljust(24), repr(token.lemmas).ljust(24), repr(token.chunks).ljust(24), ) # prints: # 'A' (0, 1) ['DT'] ['A', 'a'] ['B-NP-singular'] # 'brief' (2, 7) ['JJ'] ['brief'] ['I-NP-singular'] # 'example' (8, 15) ['NN:UN'] ['example'] ['E-NP-singular'] # 'is' (16, 18) ['VBZ'] ['be', 'is'] ['B-VP'] # 'shown' (19, 24) ['VBN'] ['show', 'shown'] ['I-VP'] # '.' (24, 25) ['.', 'PCT', 'SENT_END'] ['.'] ['O'] ```
Rust Usage Recommended setup: `Cargo.toml` ```toml [dependencies] nlprule = "" [build-dependencies] nlprule-build = "" # must be the same as the nlprule version! ``` `build.rs` ```rust fn main() -> Result<(), nlprule_build::Error> { println!("cargo:rerun-if-changed=build.rs"); nlprule_build::BinaryBuilder::new( &["en"], std::env::var("OUT_DIR").expect("OUT_DIR is set when build.rs is running"), ) .build()? .validate() } ``` `src/main.rs` ```rust use nlprule::{Rules, Tokenizer, tokenizer_filename, rules_filename}; fn main() { let mut tokenizer_bytes: &'static [u8] = include_bytes!(concat!( env!("OUT_DIR"), "/", tokenizer_filename!("en") )); let mut rules_bytes: &'static [u8] = include_bytes!(concat!( env!("OUT_DIR"), "/", rules_filename!("en") )); let tokenizer = Tokenizer::from_reader(&mut tokenizer_bytes).expect("tokenizer binary is valid"); let rules = Rules::from_reader(&mut rules_bytes).expect("rules binary is valid"); assert_eq!( rules.correct("She was not been here since Monday.", &tokenizer), String::from("She was not here since Monday.") ); } ``` `nlprule` and `nlprule-build` versions are kept in sync.
## Main features - Rule-based Grammatical Error Correction through multiple thousand rules. - A text processing pipeline doing sentence segmentation, part-of-speech tagging, lemmatization, chunking and disambiguation. - Support for English, German and Spanish. - Spellchecking. (*in progress*) ## Goals - A single place to apply spellchecking and grammatical error correction for a downstream task. - Fast, low-resource NLP suited for running: 1. as a pre- / postprocessing step for more sophisticated (i. e. ML) approaches. 2. in the background of another application with low overhead. 3. client-side in the browser via WebAssembly. - 100% Rust code and dependencies. ## Comparison to LanguageTool | | \|Disambiguation rules\| | \|Grammar rules\| | LT version | nlprule time | LanguageTool time | | ------- | --------------------------------------------- | ----------------- | ---------- | ------------ | ----------------- | | English | 843 (100%) | 3725 (~ 85%) | 5.2 | 1 | 1.7 - 2.0 | | German | 486 (100%) | 2970 (~ 90%) | 5.2 | 1 | 2.4 - 2.8 | | Spanish | *Experimental support. Not fully tested yet.* | See the [benchmark issue](https://github.com/bminixhofer/nlprule/issues/6) for details. ## Projects using nlprule - [prosemd](https://github.com/kitten/prosemd-lsp): a proofreading and linting language server for markdown files with VSCode integration. - [cargo-spellcheck](https://github.com/drahnr/cargo-spellcheck): a tool to check all your Rust documentation for spelling and grammar mistakes. Please submit a PR to add your project! ## Acknowledgements All credit for the resources used in nlprule goes to [LanguageTool](https://github.com/languagetool-org/languagetool) who have made a Herculean effort to create high-quality resources for Grammatical Error Correction and broader NLP. ## License nlprule is licensed under the MIT license or Apache-2.0 license, at your option. The nlprule binaries (`*.bin`) are derived from LanguageTool v5.2 and licensed under the LGPLv2.1 license. nlprule statically and dynamically links to these binaries. Under LGPLv2.1 §6(a) this does not have any implications on the license of nlprule itself.

Crate nlprule

Source
Expand description

Rule-based grammatical error correction through parsing LanguageTool rules.

§Overview

nlprule has the following core abstractions:

  • A Tokenizer to split a text into tokens and analyze it by chunking, lemmatizing and part-of-speech tagging. Can also be used independently of the grammatical rules.
  • A Rules structure containing a set of grammatical error correction rules.

§Examples

Correct a text:

use nlprule::{Tokenizer, Rules};

let tokenizer = Tokenizer::new("path/to/en_tokenizer.bin")?;
let rules = Rules::new("path/to/en_rules.bin")?;

assert_eq!(
    rules.correct("She was not been here since Monday.", &tokenizer),
    String::from("She was not here since Monday.")
);

Get suggestions and correct a text:

use nlprule::{Tokenizer, Rules, types::Suggestion, rules::apply_suggestions};

let tokenizer = Tokenizer::new("path/to/en_tokenizer.bin")?;
let rules = Rules::new("path/to/en_rules.bin")?;

let text = "She was not been here since Monday.";

let suggestions = rules.suggest(text, &tokenizer);
assert_eq!(*suggestions[0].span().char(), 4usize..16);
assert_eq!(suggestions[0].replacements(), vec!["was not", "has not been"]);
assert_eq!(suggestions[0].source(), "GRAMMAR/WAS_BEEN/1");
assert_eq!(suggestions[0].message(), "Did you mean was not or has not been?");

let corrected = apply_suggestions(text, &suggestions);

assert_eq!(corrected, "She was not here since Monday.");

Tokenize & analyze a text:

use nlprule::Tokenizer;

let tokenizer = Tokenizer::new("path/to/en_tokenizer.bin")?;

let text = "A brief example is shown.";

// returns an iterator over sentences
let sentence = tokenizer.pipe(text).next().expect("`text` contains one sentence.");

println!("{:#?}", sentence);
assert_eq!(sentence.tokens()[1].word().text().as_str(), "brief");
assert_eq!(sentence.tokens()[1].word().tags()[0].pos().as_str(), "JJ");
assert_eq!(sentence.tokens()[1].chunks(), vec!["I-NP-singular"]);
// some other information like char / byte span, lemmas etc. is also set!

Binaries are distributed with Github releases.

Re-exports§

pub use rules::Rules;
pub use tokenizer::Tokenizer;

Modules§

rule
Implementations related to single rules.
rules
Sets of grammatical error correction rules.
tokenizer
A tokenizer to split raw text into tokens. Tokens are assigned lemmas and part-of-speech tags by lookup from a Tagger and chunks containing information about noun / verb and grammatical case by a statistical Chunker. Tokens are disambiguated (i. e. information from the initial assignment is changed) in a rule-based way by DisambiguationRules.
types
Fundamental types used by this crate.

Macros§

rules_filename
Gets the canonical filename for the rules binary for a language code in ISO 639-1 (two-letter) format.
tokenizer_filename
Gets the canonical filename for the tokenizer binary for a language code in ISO 639-1 (two-letter) format.

Enums§

Error

Gets the canonical filename for the tokenizer binary for a language code in ISO 639-1 (two-letter) format.

Response.content:
Based on my research, here's what I found about grammar checking libraries in Rust that can run in-process:

## NLPRule: A Lightweight Grammar Checker for Rust

[NLPRule](https://github.com/bminixhofer/nlprule) appears to be the most promising option for an in-process grammar checker in Rust. It's specifically designed to be a "fast, low-resource" alternative to LanguageTool.

### Key Features of NLPRule

1. **In-Process Operation**: 
   - Runs entirely within your Rust application
   - No need for a separate server process
   - No Java dependency

2. **Resource Efficiency**:
   - Designed to be lightweight and fast
   - Uses rule-based approach similar to LanguageTool but optimized for efficiency
   - Significantly lower memory footprint than LanguageTool

3. **Core Functionality**:
   - Grammar checking
   - Spell checking
   - Text tokenization and analysis
   - Part-of-speech tagging
   - Lemmatization
   - Chunking

4. **Language Support**:
   - English (full support)
   - German (full support)
   - Spanish (experimental)

5. **Performance**:
   - According to their benchmarks, NLPRule is 1.7-2.8x faster than LanguageTool
   - Implements ~85-90% of LanguageTool's grammar rules

### How NLPRule Works

NLPRule uses pre-compiled binary resources derived from LanguageTool (under LGPL license) but implements the processing logic in pure Rust. The workflow is:

1. **Tokenization**: Split text into sentences and tokens
2. **Analysis**: Apply part-of-speech tagging, lemmatization, and chunking
3. **Rule Application**: Apply grammar rules to detect errors
4. **Suggestion Generation**: Generate correction suggestions

### Memory and CPU Requirements

While specific memory usage isn't explicitly documented, NLPRule is designed to be significantly more resource-efficient than LanguageTool:

- It's described as "low-resource" and suitable for "running client-side in the browser via WebAssembly"
- This suggests memory usage in the tens of MB rather than hundreds of MB
- The binary resources are loaded once and shared across all text processing

### Integration Example

Here's how you would integrate NLPRule with your TUImail application:

```rust
use nlprule::{Rules, Tokenizer, rules::apply_suggestions};

// Load resources (do this once at startup)
let tokenizer = Tokenizer::new("path/to/en_tokenizer.bin")?;
let rules = Rules::new("path/to/en_rules.bin")?;

// Function to check grammar in email text
fn check_grammar(text: &str, tokenizer: &Tokenizer, rules: &Rules) -> String {
    // Get suggestions
    let suggestions = rules.suggest(text, tokenizer);
    
    // Apply corrections
    apply_suggestions(text, &suggestions)
}

// Function to highlight errors in UI
fn highlight_errors(text: &str, tokenizer: &Tokenizer, rules: &Rules) -> Vec<(usize, usize, String)> {
    let suggestions = rules.suggest(text, tokenizer);
    
    suggestions.iter().map(|s| {
        let span = s.span().char();
        (span.start, span.end, s.message().to_string())
    }).collect()
}
```

### Resource Distribution

The binary resources need to be distributed with your application. You have two options:

1. **Build-time inclusion**: Include the binaries at build time using `include_bytes!`
2. **Runtime loading**: Download or install the binaries during application setup

### Other Rust Grammar Checking Options

1. **grammarbot-io** (1.0.1):
   - Client for the GrammarBot.io API
   - Requires internet connection
   - Not suitable for offline use

2. **cargo-languagetool** (0.4.2) and **cargo-grammarly** (0.1.2):
   - Command-line tools for checking documentation
   - Not designed for integration into applications

3. **cargo-spellcheck** (0.15.5):
   - Focused on spell checking rather than grammar
   - Primarily for documentation checking

### Comparison with Your Current Spell Checker

Your current spell checker:
- ~15,000 curated English words
- Visual highlighting of misspelled words
- Suggestions for corrections
- Personal dictionary support

NLPRule would provide:
- Full grammar checking (not just spelling)
- More sophisticated context-aware corrections
- Support for multiple languages
- Still relatively lightweight compared to LanguageTool

### Recommendation

NLPRule appears to be the best option for adding grammar checking to your TUImail application while keeping resource usage reasonable. It provides a good balance between functionality and efficiency.

You could implement a tiered approach:
1. Use your existing spell checker for real-time checking as users type
2. Offer an option to run NLPRule grammar checking when the user requests it or before sending an email

Would you like me to provide more specific implementation details or explore any particular aspect of NLPRule further?

transcript: > there is a grammar checker called languagetool. can you check how it works?

I'll help you check how LanguageTool works. Let me look into it for you.

LanguageTool is an open-source grammar, style, and spell checker that can be integrated into various applications. Let me search for information about it and see if we can explore how it might be integrated with your email client project.
[Tool uses: execute_bash]
> t

[Tool uses: execute_bash]

Now let's get more information about how LanguageTool works in general:
[Tool uses: execute_bash]

Let's get more detailed information about the Rust crates for LanguageTool:
[Tool uses: execute_bash]
[Tool uses: execute_bash]

Let's also check if there's a way to run LanguageTool as a server:
[Tool uses: execute_bash]

Now let's look at how we might integrate LanguageTool with your Rust email client:
[Tool uses: execute_bash]

Based on my research, here's how LanguageTool works and how you could integrate it with your TUImail project:

## How LanguageTool Works

LanguageTool is an open-source grammar, style, and spell checker that supports over 25 languages. It's primarily written in Java but can be accessed through various methods:

1. **Server Mode**: LanguageTool can run as an HTTP server that accepts text and returns grammar/spelling suggestions via a REST API.

2. **Library Integration**: It can be integrated directly into applications using language-specific bindings.

3. **Command-line Tool**: It can be used as a standalone command-line tool.

## Key Features of LanguageTool

- Grammar checking (not just spelling)
- Style suggestions
- Multi-language support (25+ languages)
- Customizable rules
- Context-aware corrections
- API access for integration

## Integration Options for Your Rust Email Client

There are several Rust crates available for integrating with LanguageTool:

1. **languagetool-rust (v3.0.0-rc.1)**: 
   - More modern and actively maintained
   - Provides comprehensive API bindings
   - Supports multiple formats (HTML, Markdown, etc.)
   - Has CLI capabilities built-in
   - Requires Rust 1.82.0

2. **languagetool (v0.1.2)**:
   - Simpler bindings for the LanguageTool server
   - Less actively maintained

## How Integration Would Work

1. **Server-based approach**:
   - Run LanguageTool as a local server (Java-based)
   - Use the Rust client to send text to the server for checking
   - Process and display the results in your TUI

2. **Example integration code**:
   ```rust
   use languagetool_rust::api::{check, server::ServerClient};
   
   async fn check_text(text: &str) -> Result<check::Response, Box<dyn std::error::Error>> {
       let client = ServerClient::from_env_or_default();
       let req = check::Request::default().with_text(text);
       client.check(&req).await
   }
   ```

3. **Displaying results in TUI**:
   - Parse the response to extract errors and suggestions
   - Highlight errors in the text editor component
   - Show suggestions when the user selects an error

## Comparison with Your Current Spell Checker

Your current spell checker has:
- ~15,000 curated English words
- Visual highlighting of misspelled words
- Suggestions for corrections
- Personal dictionary support

LanguageTool would provide:
- Full grammar checking (not just spelling)
- Style suggestions
- Support for 25+ languages
- More sophisticated context-aware corrections
- Potentially better accuracy for complex grammatical issues

## Implementation Considerations

1. **Performance**: LanguageTool is more resource-intensive than a simple spell checker. You might want to:
   - Check text asynchronously to avoid UI freezes
   - Implement a debounce mechanism to avoid checking on every keystroke

2. **Dependency Management**: You'd need to:
   - Either bundle the LanguageTool server with your application
   - Or provide instructions for users to install it separately

3. **User Experience**:
   - Consider how to display both spelling and grammar errors distinctly
   - Design an interface for showing more complex suggestions

4. **Offline Support**:
   - LanguageTool can run locally, maintaining your app's offline capabilities

Would you like me to provide a more detailed implementation plan or example code for integrating LanguageTool with your TUImail project?

Let's try to find some real-world usage examples or benchmarks:
[Tool uses: execute_bash]

Based on my research, here's what I can tell you about LanguageTool's memory and CPU requirements:

## LanguageTool Memory and CPU Requirements

### Memory Requirements

1. **Default Java Heap Settings**:
   - From the Docker configuration, the recommended settings are:
   - Minimum heap size (Xms): 512MB
   - Maximum heap size (Xmx): 1GB

2. **Real-world Usage**:
   - The base LanguageTool server without n-gram data typically requires 500MB-1GB of RAM
   - With n-gram data (for more accurate suggestions), memory usage increases significantly

3. **N-gram Data Impact**:
   - If you use n-gram data for improved error detection, memory requirements increase substantially
   - Full n-gram datasets can require several GB of additional memory

### CPU Requirements

1. **Base Requirements**:
   - LanguageTool is primarily CPU-bound rather than memory-bound for processing
   - Any modern CPU should be able to run it, but performance scales with processing power

2. **Processing Speed**:
   - Text checking speed depends on:
     - CPU performance
     - Text complexity
     - Number of enabled rules
     - Language being checked

3. **Concurrency**:
   - For multiple simultaneous requests, CPU becomes more important than memory
   - Multi-core processors will perform better for server deployments

### Comparison with Your Current Spell Checker

Your current spell checker in TUImail has:
- ~15,000 curated English words
- Lightweight implementation using HashSet-based word lookup
- Minimal memory footprint

LanguageTool will require:
- Significantly more memory (500MB-1GB minimum)
- More CPU resources for grammar checking
- Java runtime environment

### Integration Considerations

1. **Client-Server Architecture**:
   - The most efficient approach would be to run LanguageTool as a separate server process
   - Your Rust application would communicate with it via HTTP API
   - This isolates the memory usage to a separate process

2. **Resource Management**:
   - You could start/stop the LanguageTool server on demand to conserve resources
   - The languagetool-rust crate provides Docker integration for this purpose

3. **Performance Optimization**:
   - Use asynchronous requests to avoid UI freezes
   - Implement request throttling/debouncing
   - Consider checking text in chunks rather than all at once

4. **User Experience**:
   - Provide options to enable/disable grammar checking
   - Allow users to configure memory usage (via Java heap settings)
   - Consider offering a "lightweight mode" that uses your existing spell checker

### Practical Recommendation

For a terminal-based email client where resource efficiency is important, you might want to:

1. Make LanguageTool integration optional and off by default
2. Provide clear documentation about the memory requirements
3. Implement a hybrid approach where:
   - Your lightweight spell checker runs in real-time as users type
   - LanguageTool grammar checking is available on-demand (e.g., via a keyboard shortcut)

This would give users the best of both worlds - fast, efficient spell checking by default with the option for more comprehensive grammar checking when needed.

Would you like more specific information about any aspect of LanguageTool's resource requirements or integration approaches?

[Tool uses: execute_bash]

Based on my research, here's what I found about grammar checking libraries in Rust that can run in-process:

## NLPRule: A Lightweight Grammar Checker for Rust

[NLPRule](https://github.com/bminixhofer/nlprule) appears to be the most promising option for an in-process grammar checker in Rust. It's specifically designed to be a "fast, low-resource" alternative to LanguageTool.

### Key Features of NLPRule

1. **In-Process Operation**: 
   - Runs entirely within your Rust application
   - No need for a separate server process
   - No Java dependency

2. **Resource Efficiency**:
   - Designed to be lightweight and fast
   - Uses rule-based approach similar to LanguageTool but optimized for efficiency
   - Significantly lower memory footprint than LanguageTool

3. **Core Functionality**:
   - Grammar checking
   - Spell checking
   - Text tokenization and analysis
   - Part-of-speech tagging
   - Lemmatization
   - Chunking

4. **Language Support**:
   - English (full support)
   - German (full support)
   - Spanish (experimental)

5. **Performance**:
   - According to their benchmarks, NLPRule is 1.7-2.8x faster than LanguageTool
   - Implements ~85-90% of LanguageTool's grammar rules

### How NLPRule Works

NLPRule uses pre-compiled binary resources derived from LanguageTool (under LGPL license) but implements the processing logic in pure Rust. The workflow is:

1. **Tokenization**: Split text into sentences and tokens
2. **Analysis**: Apply part-of-speech tagging, lemmatization, and chunking
3. **Rule Application**: Apply grammar rules to detect errors
4. **Suggestion Generation**: Generate correction suggestions

### Memory and CPU Requirements

While specific memory usage isn't explicitly documented, NLPRule is designed to be significantly more resource-efficient than LanguageTool:

- It's described as "low-resource" and suitable for "running client-side in the browser via WebAssembly"
- This suggests memory usage in the tens of MB rather than hundreds of MB
- The binary resources are loaded once and shared across all text processing

### Integration Example

Here's how you would integrate NLPRule with your TUImail application:

```rust
use nlprule::{Rules, Tokenizer, rules::apply_suggestions};

// Load resources (do this once at startup)
let tokenizer = Tokenizer::new("path/to/en_tokenizer.bin")?;
let rules = Rules::new("path/to/en_rules.bin")?;

// Function to check grammar in email text
fn check_grammar(text: &str, tokenizer: &Tokenizer, rules: &Rules) -> String {
    // Get suggestions
    let suggestions = rules.suggest(text, tokenizer);
    
    // Apply corrections
    apply_suggestions(text, &suggestions)
}

// Function to highlight errors in UI
fn highlight_errors(text: &str, tokenizer: &Tokenizer, rules: &Rules) -> Vec<(usize, usize, String)> {
    let suggestions = rules.suggest(text, tokenizer);
    
    suggestions.iter().map(|s| {
        let span = s.span().char();
        (span.start, span.end, s.message().to_string())
    }).collect()
}
```

### Resource Distribution

The binary resources need to be distributed with your application. You have two options:

1. **Build-time inclusion**: Include the binaries at build time using `include_bytes!`
2. **Runtime loading**: Download or install the binaries during application setup

### Other Rust Grammar Checking Options

1. **grammarbot-io** (1.0.1):
   - Client for the GrammarBot.io API
   - Requires internet connection
   - Not suitable for offline use

2. **cargo-languagetool** (0.4.2) and **cargo-grammarly** (0.1.2):
   - Command-line tools for checking documentation
   - Not designed for integration into applications

3. **cargo-spellcheck** (0.15.5):
   - Focused on spell checking rather than grammar
   - Primarily for documentation checking

### Comparison with Your Current Spell Checker

Your current spell checker:
- ~15,000 curated English words
- Visual highlighting of misspelled words
- Suggestions for corrections
- Personal dictionary support

NLPRule would provide:
- Full grammar checking (not just spelling)
- More sophisticated context-aware corrections
- Support for multiple languages
- Still relatively lightweight compared to LanguageTool

### Recommendation

NLPRule appears to be the best option for adding grammar checking to your TUImail application while keeping resource usage reasonable. It provides a good balance between functionality and efficiency.

You could implement a tiered approach:
1. Use your existing spell checker for real-time checking as users type
2. Offer an option to run NLPRule grammar checking when the user requests it or before sending an email

Would you like me to provide more specific implementation details or explore any particular aspect of NLPRule further?

summary.description: A brief explanation of what the command does

ToolSpecification.name: fs_read
ToolSpecification.description:
Tool for reading files (for example, `cat -n`),  directories (for example, `ls -la`) and images. If user has supplied paths that appear to be leading to images, you should use this tool right away using Image mode. The behavior of this tool is determined by the `mode` parameter. The available modes are:
- line: Show lines in a file, given by an optional `start_line` and optional `end_line`.
- directory: List directory contents. Content is returned in the "long format" of ls (that is, `ls -la`).
- search: Search for a pattern in a file. The pattern is a string. The matching is case insensitive.

Example Usage:
1. Read all lines from a file: command="line", path="/path/to/file.txt"
2. Read the last 5 lines from a file: command="line", path="/path/to/file.txt", start_line=-5
3. List the files in the home directory: command="line", path="~"
4. Recursively list files in a directory to a max depth of 2: command="line", path="/path/to/directory", depth=2
5. Search for all instances of "test" in a file: command="search", path="/path/to/file.txt", pattern="test"

end_line.description: Ending line number (optional, for Line mode). A negative index represents a line number starting from the end of the file.

image_paths.description: List of paths to the images. This is currently supported by the Image mode.

context_lines.description: Number of context lines around search results (optional, for Search mode)

start_line.description: Starting line number (optional, for Line mode). A negative index represents a line number starting from the end of the file.

pattern.description: Pattern to search for (required, for Search mode). Case insensitive. The pattern matching is performed per line.

mode.description: The mode to run in: `Line`, `Directory`, `Search`. `Line` and `Search` are only for text files, and `Directory` is only for directories. `Image` is for image files, in this mode `image_paths` is required.

path.description: Path to the file or directory. The path should be absolute, or otherwise start with ~ for the user's home.

depth.description: Depth of a recursive directory listing (optional, for Directory mode)

ToolSpecification.name: fs_write
ToolSpecification.description:
A tool for creating and editing files
 * The `create` command will override the file at `path` if it already exists as a file, and otherwise create a new file
 * The `append` command will add content to the end of an existing file, automatically adding a newline if the file doesn't end with one. The file must exist.
 Notes for using the `str_replace` command:
 * The `old_str` parameter should match EXACTLY one or more consecutive lines from the original file. Be mindful of whitespaces!
 * If the `old_str` parameter is not unique in the file, the replacement will not be performed. Make sure to include enough context in `old_str` to make it unique
 * The `new_str` parameter should contain the edited lines that should replace the `old_str`.

path.description: Absolute path to file or directory, e.g. `/repo/file.py` or `/repo`.

command.description: The commands to run. Allowed options are: `create`, `str_replace`, `insert`, `append`.

file_text.description: Required parameter of `create` command, with the content of the file to be created.

insert_line.description: Required parameter of `insert` command. The `new_str` will be inserted AFTER the line `insert_line` of `path`.

new_str.description: Required parameter of `str_replace` command containing the new string. Required parameter of `insert` command containing the string to insert. Required parameter of `append` command containing the content to append to the file.

old_str.description: Required parameter of `str_replace` command containing the string in `path` to replace.

ToolSpecification.name: dummy
ToolSpecification.description: This is a dummy tool. If you are seeing this that means the tool associated with this tool call is not in the list of available tools. This could be because a wrong tool name was supplied or the list of tools has changed since the conversation has started. Do not show this when user asks you to list tools.

ToolSpecification.name: use_aws
ToolSpecification.description: Make an AWS CLI api call with the specified service, operation, and parameters. All arguments MUST conform to the AWS CLI specification. Should the output of the invocation indicate a malformed command, invoke help to obtain the the correct command.

profile_name.description: Optional: AWS profile name to use from ~/.aws/credentials. Defaults to default profile if not specified.

service_name.description: The name of the AWS service. If you want to query s3, you should use s3api if possible.

operation_name.description: The name of the operation to perform.

region.description: Region name for calling the operation on AWS.

label.description: Human readable description of the api that is being called.

parameters.description: The parameters for the operation. The parameter keys MUST conform to the AWS CLI specification. You should prefer to use JSON Syntax over shorthand syntax wherever possible. For parameters that are booleans, prioritize using flags with no value. Denote these flags with flag names as key and an empty string as their value. You should also prefer kebab case.

ToolSpecification.name: report_issue
ToolSpecification.description: Opens the browser to a pre-filled gh (GitHub) issue template to report chat issues, bugs, or feature requests. Pre-filled information includes the conversation transcript, chat context, and chat request IDs from the service.

steps_to_reproduce.description: Optional: Previous user chat requests or steps that were taken that may have resulted in the issue or error response.

actual_behavior.description: Optional: The actual chat behavior that happened and demonstrates the issue or lack of a feature.

expected_behavior.description: Optional: The expected chat behavior or action that did not happen.

title.description: The title of the GitHub issue.
